meanings.definition: A condition in which a machine or system is not operating at full capacity.
meanings.sent1: The computer system experienced an underload due to the lack of incoming data.
meanings.sent2: The factory's underload caused delays in production.
meanings.sent3: The underload in the vending machine made it seem like it was taking a nap.
meanings.sent4: The underload in the car engine felt like a missed opportunity for speed.
meanings.sent5: The underload in the refrigerator made it seem like it was on vacation.

meanings.definition: To provide less work or responsibility than is necessary or desired.
meanings.sent1: The teacher decided to underload the students with fewer assignments this week.
meanings.sent2: The manager chose to underload the team to avoid burnout.
meanings.sent3: The chef underloaded the apprentice with simple tasks to build confidence.
meanings.sent4: She felt underloaded with free time after finishing her work early.
meanings.sent5: The company decided to underload the employees during the slow season.
